titlestmt.subtitle: An Inventory of His Papers, 1948-1985, at the Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library
titlestmt.author: Abel Ramirez

profiledesc.creation: Text converted and initial EAD tagging provided by Apex Data Services, September 2000.

titlepage.titleproper: Inventory for the Elmer Kelton Papers, 1948-1985
titlepage.author: Abel Ramirez

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: The papers of Elmer Kelton, a prolific western writer, from 1948-1985.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, Texas Tech University

bioghist.head: Biographical Sketch
bioghist.p: A prolific western writer, Elmer Kelton was born on April 29, 1926 at Horse Camp, east of Andrews, Texas. He wrote numerous western novels including The Good Ole Boys, Honor at Daybreak, and Man Who Rode Midnight. In addition to his western novels, Kelton wrote numerous articles for The Farmer-Stockman since 1964. He has also been a writer for the San Angelo Times and served as editor for the West Texas Livestock and the Sheep and Goat Raisers Association. Since 1955, Kelton has been a member of the Western Writers of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection, donated by Kelton over the past thirty years, is arranged in thirteen series:
Series I: Papers, 1948-1985, consists of literary productions and an inventory of short stories. The items are housed within 2 wallets.

Series II: Papers, 1952-1976 and undated, consists of literary correspondence to literary agencies, abstracts, magazine articles, manuscripts, and six cowboy photographs. The items are housed within 9 boxes.
Series III: Papers, 1964-1997 and undated, consists of manuscripts, magazine articles, printed and scrapbook materials. The items are housed within 6 boxes.
Series IV: Papers, 1968-1981 and undated, consists of correspondence and manuscripts. The items are housed within 1 box.
Series V: Papers, 1971-1987 and undated, consists of manuscripts. The items are housed within 1 box.

Series VI: Papers, 1973-1993, consists of manuscript proofs and correspondence regarding The Art of James Bama, as well as correspondence, convention materials, and financial material on the Western Writers of America association. The items are housed within 1 box.
Series VII: Papers, 1977-1980 and undated, consists of manuscripts and manuscript proofs. The items are housed within 2 boxes.
Series VIII: Papers, 1980-1981 and undated, consists of correspondence and manuscripts. The items are housed within 1 box.
Series IX: Papers, 1984 and undated, consists of manuscripts. The items are housed within 1 box.
Series X: Papers, 1985, consists of correspondence and manuscript proofs. The items are housed within 1 wallet.
Series XI: Papers, 1988, consists of speeches. The items are housed within 1 wallet.
Series XII: Papers, 1989, consists of speeches. The items are housed within 1 wallet.

Series XIII: Papers, 1993, consists of manuscripts proofs, the bulk of which deal with the manuscript of Elmer Kelton Country: The Short Nonfiction of a Texas Novelist. The items are housed within 1 box.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: The subject headings used by the Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library are derived from the Library of Congress and/or locally developed.

controlaccess.head: Subjects (Organizations)
controlaccess.corpname: National Cowboy Hall of Fame and Western Heritage Center--Awards

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Elmer Kelton Papers, 1948-1985 , Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, Texas

bibliography.head: Additional Sources
bibliography.bibref: Connor, Seymour V., ed. Builders of the Southwest. Lubbock: Southwest Collection, Texas Technological College, 1959.
Clayton, Lawrence. Elmer Kelton. Idaho: Boise State University, 1986.
Alter, Judy. Elmer Kelton and West Texas: a Literary Relationship. Denton.: University of North Texas Press, 1989, c1988.
Blanton, Ira Yates. The Triumph of Tradition in Six Novels of Elmer Kelton, 1971-1998. Thesis (Ph.D.)--Texas Tech University, 1999.
